awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Telomerase Regulation in Deep Branching Eukaryotes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine telomerase function in the early lineage of eukaryotic evolution. Telomerase is an enzyme that is responsible for making telomeres, structures that protect the ends of all eukaryotic chromosomes, reminiscent of the hard ends of shoelaces. The genetic mechanism of telomere replication by telomerase is better studied in yeast and mammalian cells; far from each other as those two organisms are, they in fact represent relatively recent branches of eukaryotic phylogeny. In contrast, we study an ancient, deep branching lineage of eukaryotes, kinetoplastid protists. Our organism of choice, Trypanosoma brucei, has telomerase with unique structural and functional properties, and we will learn how this enzyme works. The project will encourage full participation from women and underrepresented minorities in science. Apart from training graduate and postdoctoral trainees, this project will also implement a three-year undergraduate program (BIOKEYS) in both PIs? laboratories; the major goal of this program will be to teach undergraduate researchers to value interdisciplinary sciences early in their research careers. In addition to gaining experience from designing experiments and problem solving using high-end technologies, students will be teaching and learning from each other as part of a research group.

Telomerase, a ribonucleoprotein enzyme, provides the major means for elongation of chromosome ends (telomeres), thus counteracting the loss of linear DNA ends in each cell cycle due to incomplete DNA replication by conventional DNA polymerases. Telomerase has two core components, the Telomerase Reverse Transcriptase (TERT) that catalyzes telomere elongation, and the telomerase RNA (TER), which provides a template for telomere DNA synthesis. The mechanisms of telomere elongation by telomerase are poorly understood in Trypanosoma brucei, a deep branching Kinetoplastid. Therefore, this project dissects structural, biochemical and genetic features of telomerase RNA in T. brucei to understand the mechanism of telomerase regulation in early eukaryotic species. The recent discovery of the T. brucei TER reveals novel features exclusive to deep branching eukaryotes, suggesting mechanistic differences in the process of telomere synthesis between T. brucei and higher eukaryotic organisms. Therefore, this project: (i) investigates telomerase RNA structure at a single nucleotide resolution using NMR and SHAPE chemistry, (ii) defines key TERT contact sites on TER that are essential for telomerase function in T. brucei using HITS-CLIP technology, and (iii) establishes the functional significance of TR domains by genetic manipulations and telomerase functional assays. Overall, this research will allow significant advances in understanding the mechanistic details of telomerase evolution in protists.

por.por_cntn:
Eukaryotic organisms have linear chromosomes and their ends are called telomeres, which are protein/DNA complexes that are essential for genome integrity and unlimited cell proliferation ability. The eukaryotic parasite Trypanosoma brucei causes fatal sleeping sickness in humans, and telomeres are also essential for the parasite survival in the mammalian host. In addition, Trypanosoma brucei sequentially expresses immunologically distinct Variant Surface Glycoproteins (VSGs), its major surface antigen, to evade the host?s immune response and to establish a long-term infection. VSGs are expressed exclusively from regions adjacent to the telomere. In addition, although Trypanosoma brucei has more than 2,500 VSG genes in its genome, only one VSG gene is expressed at any moment. Work from my lab has demonstrated that proteins associated with the telomere are essential regulators that control VSG expression and switching.

 

Proper telomere maintenance is extremely important for Trypanosoma brucei, because 1) telomeres are essential for genome stability; and 2) the telomere structure plays important roles in VSG regulation. However, conventional DNA polymerases cannot fully replicate the ends of linear DNA molecules, and the telomere is maintained by a specialized reverse transcriptase, telomerase, in many eukaryotes, including humans and Trypanosoma brucei.

 

Telomerase is an RNA-protein complex. It contains a protein subunit, telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT), which catalyzes the telomere DNA synthesis, and an RNA subunit, telomerase RNA (TR), which provides a short sequence as the template for the de novo telomere DNA synthesis. As a collaboration with Dr. Chakrabarti at Univ. of North Carolina Charlotte, we have identified the Trypanosoma brucei telomerase RNA gene (TbTR). In this NSF-funded project, we focused on examining the secondary structure of TbTR, its interaction with TbTERT, and the function of individual domains of TbTR.

 

As a collaboration with Dr. Chakrabarti, using an in vivo RNA chemical probing read by mutational profiling method, we recently determined the secondary structure of TbTR?s catalytic core, including its template region, the template-upstream Template Boundary Element (TBE), the template-downstream Template Proximal Helix (TPH), Main Stem Helix, and Template Distal Helix (TDH). This part of findings have published: Dey et al. 2021 Nucleic Acids Research 49: 12445.

 

Based on the domain structure of TbTR, we have made several mutant strains. First, we deleted both alleles of the TbTR gene in Trypanosoma brucei and established the TbTR null strain. As shown in our previous publication (Sandhu et al. 2013. Cell Research. 23:537), wild type Trypanosoma brucei continuously elongates its telomeres, while telomeres in TbTR null cells shorten continuously. To the TbTR null cells, we introduced various TbTR mutants. These include domain deletion mutants: ∆template, ∆TDH-5?, ∆TBE, ∆TPH, ∆Helix IV, and ∆3? CD and several point mutations.

 

We first examined the expression of mutant TbTR by northern hybridization and identified the CD box as an essential domain for TbTR expression. We then examined the interaction between TbTERT and TbTR mutants and identified several functional domain of TbTR are important for TbTR to interact with TbTERT. We have also examined the telomere maintenance in cells expressing various TbTR mutants and found that all functional domains of TbTR are important for telomere elongation. Currently we are preparing the manuscript reporting this part of work. We have also started to examine the detailed TbTR-TbTERT interaction interface using a high-throughput approach.

 

In addition, we have published a paper reporting that the telomerase activity is essential for the telomere 3? overhang structure in Trypanosoma brucei: Sandhu & Li. 2017. Scientific Reports 7:15983. Furthermore, as a collaboration with Dr. Chakrabarti, we have pulled-down the telomere complex and identified protein factors that interact with TbTERT. We have just submitted a manuscript reporting this part of work.

 

With the support from NSF, we have advanced our understanding about telomere maintenance mechanisms in the disease-causing trypanosomes. We have also enrolled five undergraduate students and two postdocs in this project. All undergraduate students did not have any biological research experience when they joined our lab. We provided a hands-on research opportunity for these undergraduate students who all stayed in the biomedical field. Three students are in medical schools now, and one worked as a technician in an urgent care center. We provided trainings for these students including many basic skills used in a molecular biology research lab. With the training we provided, the two postdocs have also grown significantly. They have improved their research skills, critical thinking and analytical skills, and presentation skills. Our research results have been reported in international conferences including Molecular Parasitology Meeting, Kinetoplastid Molecular and Cell Biology meeting, Cold Spring Harbor Telomere and Telomerase meeting, and the US Midwest Rustbelt RNA meeting.
